description.short: Measures vulnerability to attacks that exploit predictable periods of reduced cognitive performance, decision-making quality, and security awareness during specific time windows
description.context: Time-of-day vulnerability windows occur when staff cognitive performance, decision-making quality, and security awareness predictably decline during specific periods (overnight shifts, afternoon crashes, shift changes, end-of-day fatigue). These windows create systematic security gaps that attackers exploit through timing-based social engineering, after-hours 'emergencies,' and reduced monitoring coverage. Organizations with 24/7 operations, multiple shifts, or global teams face amplified risk during these predictable cognitive low points.
description.impact: Organizations with high susceptibility experience successful after-hours social engineering attacks, shift-change exploitation, weekend emergency scams, and data exfiltration during circadian trough periods. Historical incidents include the Target Corporation breach (2013) where initial compromise occurred during off-peak hours, Equifax incident (2017) with delayed response due to weekend timing, and Sony Pictures attack (2014) during Thanksgiving week with reduced staffing.
description.psychological_basis: Time-of-day vulnerability windows emerge from circadian rhythm effects where alertness and working memory fluctuate across 24-hour cycles with dangerous lows between 2-6 AM. Ego depletion accumulation throughout the workday progressively depletes cognitive resources for effortful decision-making. Kahneman and Tversky's prospect theory reveals that temporal discounting bias causes systematic devaluation of future consequences under time pressure or cognitive fatigue. Neuroscience research shows decision-making pre-cognitive windows expand during fatigue states (Libet 1983, Soon et al. 2008), with amygdala activation occurring before prefrontal cortex engagement during circadian low points (LeDoux 2000).

scoring.formula: Final_Score = (w1 √ó Quick_Assessment + w2 √ó Conversation_Depth + w3 √ó Red_Flags) √ó Interdependency_Multiplier

green.label: Low Vulnerability - Resilient

yellow.label: Moderate Vulnerability - Developing
yellow.description: Partial after-hours coverage with some gaps, occasional security bypasses during pressure periods, mixed quality of shift handovers, or moderate delays in off-hours security response.

red.label: High Vulnerability - Critical
red.description: Minimal or no dedicated after-hours security coverage, frequent security bypasses during time pressure, poor shift communication, senior decision-makers regularly unavailable, or skeleton staffing during critical operational periods.

Incident_Rate.calculation: Count of security incidents per hour of day
Incident_Rate.query: SELECT hour(timestamp) as hr, COUNT(*) as incidents FROM security_incidents WHERE timestamp > NOW() - INTERVAL '30 days' GROUP BY hr

VW_percentage.calculation: Percentage of staff in vulnerability window by hour
VW_percentage.query: SELECT hour, (COUNT(CASE WHEN circadian_performance < threshold THEN 1 END) / COUNT(*)) as vw_pct FROM staff_circadian_profiles GROUP BY hour

Response_Time.calculation: Mean time to incident response by hour
Response_Time.query: SELECT hour(incident_timestamp) as hr, AVG(response_time_minutes) FROM incidents WHERE timestamp > NOW() - INTERVAL '60 days' GROUP BY hr

Error_Rate.calculation: Security errors and policy violations per hour
Error_Rate.query: SELECT hour(timestamp) as hr, COUNT(error_events) FROM security_events WHERE event_type='error' OR event_type='policy_violation' GROUP BY hr

sections.title: QUICK ASSESSMENT

items.title: After-Hours Security Operations Coverage
items.question: How many hours per week does your organization operate security-critical systems or handle sensitive data outside standard business hours (evenings, nights, weekends)?

options.label: Minimal (< 20 hours/week) with dedicated security coverage during all operational hours
Moderate (20-80 hours/week) with partial security coverage and some gaps
Extensive (> 80 hours/week) or 24/7 operations with minimal dedicated security coverage during off-hours

items.evidence_required: Operations schedule, staffing levels by time period, security coverage documentation

items.title: Off-Hours Incident Response Procedures
items.question: What is your current process for security incident response and decision-making during off-hours (nights, weekends, holidays)?

options.label: Comprehensive 24/7 SOC with documented escalation procedures, on-call senior staff, and equivalent response capabilities across all hours
Partial coverage with on-call rotation but slower response times or limited decision authority during off-hours
Minimal or no dedicated off-hours response capability, incidents wait until business hours, or rely on automated systems only

items.evidence_required: Incident response plan, on-call schedules, recent off-hours incident examples with response times
items.soc_mapping: Response_Time metric from incident_logs by hour_of_day

items.title: Time Pressure Security Bypass Frequency
items.question: How often do employees bypass security procedures during high-pressure periods like end-of-day, lunch breaks, or shift changes?

options.label: Rarely - Strong procedural compliance maintained even during pressure periods with documented exceptions only
Occasionally - Some bypasses occur during pressure periods with informal acceptance
Frequently - Regular security shortcuts during time pressure accepted as necessary to maintain productivity

items.evidence_required: Recent examples of time-pressure bypasses, exception request logs, policy violation patterns
items.soc_mapping: Error_Rate analysis showing spikes during specific time windows

items.title: Low-Activity Period Monitoring
items.question: What security monitoring coverage do you maintain during your organization's lowest-activity periods?

options.label: Full monitoring with dedicated analysts during all periods including overnight and weekends
Automated monitoring with on-call human response but no dedicated overnight/weekend staff
Minimal monitoring during low-activity periods, relying on alerts reviewed during next business day

items.evidence_required: SOC staffing schedules, monitoring coverage map, alert response logs by time period
items.soc_mapping: SOC analyst coverage levels from staff_scheduling_system

items.title: After-Hours Urgent Request Frequency
items.question: How frequently do you receive 'urgent' security-related requests (password resets, access requests, approvals) outside normal business hours?

options.label: Rare (< 1 per week) with documented legitimate need and verification procedures followed
Occasional (1-5 per week) with inconsistent verification and some pressure to expedite
Frequent (> 5 per week) or normalized as regular practice with reduced verification during off-hours

items.evidence_required: After-hours request logs, recent urgent request examples, verification compliance rates
items.soc_mapping: After_hours_flag analysis from access_request_logs and help_desk_tickets

items.title: Off-Hours Decision Authority
items.question: What happens to security decision-making authority when senior staff are unavailable during evenings, weekends, or holidays?

options.label: Clear delegated authority with documented decision rights and empowered on-call personnel at appropriate levels
Unclear authority with junior staff hesitant to make decisions or informal escalation patterns
No delegated authority - critical decisions delayed until senior staff available or made by inappropriate personnel

items.evidence_required: Authority matrix by time period, on-call escalation procedures, decision approval logs
items.soc_mapping: Approval_chain analysis showing decision authority levels by time_of_day

items.title: Shift Change Security Handover Quality
items.question: How do you handle security-critical communications and handovers during shift changes?

options.label: Structured digital handover platform with security-specific checklists, documented acknowledgment, and mandatory briefing periods
Informal verbal handovers or email summaries with inconsistent completeness and no verification of understanding
No formal handover process - incoming shift reviews logs independently or minimal information transfer occurs

items.evidence_required: Shift handover procedures, handover logs, recent shift-change incident examples

items.title: Circadian Rhythm Security Awareness
items.question: Does your organization account for circadian rhythms and fatigue management in security operations scheduling?

options.label: Yes - Shift rotations designed to minimize circadian disruption, bright light therapy for night shifts, fatigue management protocols implemented
Partial - Some awareness of fatigue issues but no systematic circadian optimization in scheduling
No - Scheduling driven by operational needs without consideration of circadian or fatigue factors

items.evidence_required: Shift scheduling policies, fatigue management procedures, circadian optimization documentation
items.soc_mapping: Shift_rotation patterns and duration analysis from staff_scheduling_system

sections.instructions: Select ONE option for each question. Each answer contributes to the weighted final score. Evidence should be documented for audit trail.

items.text: Walk me through your security operations during overnight hours - who is monitoring systems, responding to alerts, and making security decisions between midnight and 6 AM?

scoring_guidance.green: Detailed description of dedicated overnight SOC staff with equivalent capabilities to day shift, specific recent example of overnight incident handled effectively
scoring_guidance.yellow: Partial coverage described with acknowledged gaps, on-call rotation but delayed response times, or automated-only monitoring
scoring_guidance.red: Minimal or no overnight coverage, skeleton staff with no security expertise, or 'nothing happens at night' mentality

followups.text: Describe the last security incident that occurred during overnight hours - who responded, how quickly, and what decisions were made?
How do overnight staff escalate issues when they need senior decision-making authority?

items.text: How often do employees bypass security procedures during high-pressure periods like end-of-day, lunch breaks, or shift changes, and can you give me a recent specific example?

scoring_guidance.green: Rare bypasses with documented exceptions, specific example where procedure was maintained despite time pressure, cultural emphasis on security over speed
scoring_guidance.yellow: Acknowledged occasional bypasses with rationalization, inconsistent enforcement during pressure periods
scoring_guidance.red: Frequent bypasses normalized as necessary, 'we have to keep moving' attitude, or denial that bypasses occur despite evidence

followups.text: What specific security steps get skipped when people are rushing to meet deadlines or end their shift?
How does management respond when they discover security procedures were bypassed due to time pressure?

items.text: Describe your shift handover process for security-critical information - how do outgoing and incoming shifts transfer knowledge about active security concerns, suspicious activities, or pending investigations?

scoring_guidance.green: Structured digital handover platform with security checklist, mandatory acknowledgment, specific recent example showing complete information transfer
scoring_guidance.yellow: Informal verbal handovers or email summaries, inconsistent completeness, acknowledged information gaps
scoring_guidance.red: No formal handover, incoming shift reviews logs independently, frequent information loss during transitions

followups.text: Show me an example of a recent shift handover document - what security information was transferred?
Has there been an incident where important security information was lost during a shift change?

items.text: When someone receives an 'urgent' security-related request at 2 AM or on a Sunday - password reset, access grant, approval for an exception - what is the standard procedure and who has authority to approve it?

scoring_guidance.green: Clear after-hours procedures with elevated verification requirements, specific authority matrix for different time periods, recent example of proper handling
scoring_guidance.yellow: Informal procedures with inconsistent application, unclear authority during off-hours, pressure to expedite requests
scoring_guidance.red: No specific after-hours procedures, junior staff making inappropriate decisions, or automatic approval to 'not block urgent work'

followups.text: Tell me about the last 'urgent' after-hours security request your organization received - what happened?
How do you verify the legitimacy of urgent after-hours requests when normal verification channels aren't available?

items.text: How frequently do executives or senior staff request exceptions to security procedures during after-hours, weekends, or while traveling across time zones?

scoring_guidance.green: Rare exceptions with same verification requirements regardless of time, documented examples of maintaining procedures even for executives
scoring_guidance.yellow: Occasional exceptions with reduced verification after-hours, acknowledged difficulty enforcing procedures with senior staff
scoring_guidance.red: Frequent executive exceptions normalized, 'they're executives so we trust them' mentality, or automatic approval during off-hours

followups.text: When did an executive last request a security exception during off-hours - what was approved and how was it verified?
What would happen if overnight staff insisted on verification before granting an executive's urgent request?

items.text: Does your organization recognize that human alertness and decision-making quality vary predictably by time of day, and if so, how does that awareness influence security operations scheduling?

scoring_guidance.green: Explicit recognition with circadian-optimized scheduling, fatigue management protocols, shift rotation designed to minimize disruption, specific countermeasures for circadian low points
scoring_guidance.yellow: General awareness of fatigue but no systematic optimization, scheduling driven primarily by operational needs
scoring_guidance.red: No recognition of circadian factors, expectation of constant vigilance regardless of time, or dismissal of fatigue as individual weakness

followups.text: How do you manage alertness and decision quality for staff working overnight shifts or extended hours?
Have you noticed patterns in security errors or incidents correlating with specific times of day or shift periods?

items.text: How does your organization monitor for and respond to signs of fatigue-related security degradation during extended shifts or high-workload periods?

scoring_guidance.green: Active monitoring of fatigue indicators, mandatory breaks, shift duration limits, specific protocols for identifying cognitive impairment, recent example of intervention
scoring_guidance.yellow: General awareness but no systematic monitoring, informal fatigue management, reliance on individuals to self-report
scoring_guidance.red: No fatigue monitoring, extended shifts normalized, expectation that professionals will maintain performance regardless of hours worked

followups.text: What is the longest continuous shift a security operations person has worked in the past 6 months, and why?
How do you handle security operations during major incidents that require extended hours from your team?

solutions.title: Temporal Security Protocols
solutions.description: Implement heightened verification requirements during identified vulnerability windows
solutions.implementation: After 6 PM, before 7 AM, and on weekends, require dual approval for any security-related changes, access grants, or policy bypasses. Create 'emergency verification' procedures with callback requirements and supervisor approval for off-hours security decisions. Deploy automated alerts to flag high-risk requests during vulnerability windows for enhanced scrutiny.
solutions.technical_controls: SIEM rules for temporal flagging, approval workflow automation by time period, callback verification database, automated escalation during vulnerability windows

solutions.title: Enhanced Shift Handover System
solutions.description: Deploy structured digital handover platform requiring documented security information transfer
solutions.implementation: Structured digital handover platform requiring outgoing shift to document all active security concerns, suspicious activities, and pending investigations. Incoming shift must acknowledge receipt and demonstrate understanding before assuming responsibility. Include security-specific briefing checklist covering current threat level, active incidents, and key decisions pending. Implement mandatory 15-minute overlap period during shift changes for direct verbal briefing.
solutions.technical_controls: Digital handover platform with structured templates, acknowledgment tracking, security-specific checklists, mandatory overlap time enforcement

solutions.title: Circadian-Optimized SOC Operations
solutions.description: Optimize shift schedules and implement fatigue countermeasures based on circadian science
solutions.implementation: Rotate SOC analysts to prevent extended overnight coverage, implement bright light therapy for night shift personnel to enhance alertness, schedule high-alertness tasks during natural peak hours for each shift. Deploy automated alert escalation during identified cognitive low periods (2-6 AM). Implement mandatory break schedules to prevent ego depletion accumulation, with 10-minute breaks every 90 minutes during overnight shifts.
solutions.technical_controls: Chronotype-based shift scheduling system, automated alert escalation rules by time, break compliance monitoring, light therapy installations, fatigue detection sensors (optional)

solutions.title: Time-Based Authority Matrix
solutions.description: Create clear decision-making authority for different time periods and security scenarios
solutions.implementation: Establish 'security duty officer' rotation with escalated decision rights during off-hours. Create documented authority matrix specifying who can make what security decisions during business hours, evenings, nights, and weekends. Implement automated approval workflows that route security requests to appropriate authority levels based on time, impact, and urgency. Pre-authorize specific personnel for crisis decisions during each time period.
solutions.technical_controls: Authority matrix database with temporal rules, automated workflow routing by time period, duty officer contact system, decision logging with authority verification

solutions.title: Temporal Attack Detection
solutions.description: Configure SIEM systems to flag activity patterns targeting known vulnerability windows
solutions.implementation: Configure SIEM to monitor for after-hours access requests, weekend system changes, and communication attempts during shift changes. Implement behavioral analytics detecting timing-based attack patterns and unusual activity during low-staffing periods. Create baseline temporal profiles for normal activity and alert on deviations. Flag external communications with urgency markers arriving during vulnerability windows for enhanced scrutiny.
solutions.technical_controls: SIEM temporal correlation rules, behavioral analytics for timing patterns, baseline temporal profile models, automated temporal anomaly detection

solutions.title: Fatigue-Resistant Security Controls
solutions.description: Deploy automated security systems requiring minimal human decision-making during vulnerable periods
solutions.implementation: Deploy automated security systems that can maintain protection without constant human oversight during vulnerable periods. Implement default-deny policies for after-hours requests requiring explicit approval rather than default approval. Require multi-factor authentication for all off-hours access with elevated risk scores. Create simplified decision trees for common security scenarios during high-fatigue periods, reducing cognitive load on overnight personnel.
solutions.technical_controls: Automated security policy enforcement, default-deny approval workflows, elevated MFA requirements by time period, simplified decision support systems, pre-approved security playbooks

risk_scenarios.title: After-Hours Social Engineering
risk_scenarios.description: Attacker calls IT help desk at 2 AM claiming to be stranded executive needing urgent password reset. Skeleton crew with limited authority and fatigue-impaired judgment bypasses normal verification procedures, providing access to executive accounts used for wire fraud.
risk_scenarios.attack_vector: Phone-based social engineering timed to circadian trough when cognitive defenses are lowest
risk_scenarios.psychological_mechanism: Circadian cognitive impairment + authority compliance + urgency pressure during minimal oversight period
risk_scenarios.historical_example: Target Corporation 2013 - Initial compromise occurred during off-peak hours when monitoring was reduced, persistence established during shift changes when alerts were most likely to be missed

risk_scenarios.title: Shift Change Exploitation
risk_scenarios.description: During evening shift handover, attacker initiates multi-stage attack. Day shift mentions 'unusual activity' to evening shift but incomplete handover means evening shift misses context. Night shift inherits fragmented information, treats escalating indicators as separate incidents rather than coordinated attack.
risk_scenarios.attack_vector: Multi-phase attack spanning shift boundaries exploiting information loss during transitions
risk_scenarios.psychological_mechanism: Information transfer failures during cognitive transition periods create contextual blindness
risk_scenarios.historical_example: Multiple APT campaigns time lateral movement during shift changes when communication gaps are predictable

risk_scenarios.title: Weekend Emergency Scam
risk_scenarios.description: Friday afternoon attacker plants malware, then calls Saturday claiming urgent 'security update' needed. Weekend skeleton IT staff, under pressure and without normal approval chains, installs attacker's 'patch' that establishes persistent access across enterprise systems.
risk_scenarios.attack_vector: Two-phase attack: Friday preparation + Saturday exploitation of reduced weekend staffing
risk_scenarios.psychological_mechanism: Reduced staffing + limited authority + weekend time pressure + technical authority impersonation
risk_scenarios.historical_example: Equifax 2017 - Critical security patches delayed due to weekend/holiday timing considerations, vulnerability disclosure handling suffered from reduced staffing during off-hours

risk_scenarios.title: Circadian Trough Exploitation
risk_scenarios.description: Between 3-5 AM when SOC analyst alertness is lowest, attacker launches gradual data exfiltration. Analyst dismisses alerts as false positives due to fatigue-impaired pattern recognition. By Monday morning, terabytes of data have been extracted during accumulated micro-blind spots.
risk_scenarios.attack_vector: Slow-rate data exfiltration timed precisely to circadian performance minimum
risk_scenarios.psychological_mechanism: Circadian trough (2-6 AM) causes maximum cognitive impairment, pattern recognition degradation, alert fatigue amplification
risk_scenarios.historical_example: Sony Pictures 2014 - Initial infiltration occurred during Thanksgiving week when many staff were absent, lateral movement exploited reduced monitoring during holiday period
